patches.reasoning: Identifying the foundational knowledge pupils should have before this lesson.

value: The Romans invaded Britain in AD 43.
Roman Britain was part of the Roman Empire for nearly 400 years.
The Roman Empire was large and included many countries.
Romans built roads and towns in Britain.
The Roman army was strong and well-organised.

patches.reasoning: Highlighting the main learning points pupils should take from this lesson.

value: The Roman Empire began to weaken due to internal and external pressures.
Romans left Britain around AD 410 to defend other parts of the Empire.
Britain experienced changes in governance and defence after the Romans left.
Roman influence remained in Britain's culture, architecture, and roads.
The end of Roman rule marked the beginning of new challenges for Britain.

patches.reasoning: Addressing common misconceptions to ensure accurate understanding of the topic.

value.misconception: Romans left Britain because they were defeated by locals
value.description: The Romans left due to pressures on other parts of the Empire and internal issues, not because they were defeated by locals.

value.misconception: All Roman influence disappeared after they left
value.description: Many aspects of Roman culture, architecture, and infrastructure remained in Britain even after their departure.

patches.reasoning: Providing key vocabulary to support understanding of the topic.

value.definition: A large group of countries or regions controlled by one ruler or government.
Having an effect on the character, development, or behaviour of someone or something.
An instance of invading a country with an armed force.
The way that a city, company, etc., is controlled by those in power.
